With reference to Article 63 of the Persian Coast and Islands Order in Council, 1907, I have the honour to submit the following report on the opera tion of the Order in Council for the year ending 31st December 1915 for transmission to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. 2. Jurisdiction. The following changes took place in the year under report among officers exercising judicial powers under the Order : — Lieutenant-Colonel R. L. Kennion relieved Major A. P. Trevor, C.I.E., on 10th April as Subordinate Judge and Magistrate of the First Class within the limits of the province of Arabistan. Major R. E. A. Hamilton relieved Captain W. G. Neale, on 19th April, as District Magistrate and Judicial Assistant to His Majesty’s Consul-General at Bushire. On the transfer of Major Hamilton to Basrah, Major A. P. Trevor, C.I.E., was invested with the powers. He was later on relieved by Captain M. E. Rae, who continued in office until the close of the year. Mr. W. R. Howson, who also exercises the powers of a Magistrate of the First Class and Subordinate Judge at Lingah, relieved Captain H. V. Biscoe at Bunder Abbas on 13th March. He was invested with the usual Magis terial and Judicial powers in September. 3. Civil and Criminal. (a) Civil. (1) Thirteen civil suits were filed in the Court of His Majesty’s Consul, Mohammerah, during the year under report. Two cases were dismissed and judgment in eleven cases was in favour of the plaintiffs. (2) One civil suit was filed in the Court of His Majesty’s Consul, Bunder Abbas, during the year under report. The judgment was in favour of the plaintiff. (3) No civil suits were filed in any other Court within the limits of the Order. (5) Criminal. (1) One criminal case was tried in the Court of the District Magistrate and Judicial Assistant to His Majesty’s Consul-General at Bushire during the year under report. The accused, a coloured fireman of a merchant vessel, was found guilty of an offence under the Merchant Shipping Act and sentenced to eight weeks’ simple imprisonment. The sentence was carried out in the Karachi Jail. (2) Three criminal suits were filed in the Court of His Majesty’s Consul at Mohammerah during the year under report. In the first case the accused was tried for theft, but as no charge was framed, the case was dismissed. In the second case the accused was tried for voluntarily causing hurt. The parties, however, compromised the case out of Court. The third case w 7 as for theft. The accused was found guilty and sentenced to two months’ rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 50 or in default of payment to another month’s imprisonment. The sentence was carried out and fine paid. (3) One criminal case of alleged theft of property valued at Krans 4,000 was tried in the Court of His Majesty’s Consul, Kerman. The case was, how ever, dismissed for want of evidence against the accused. (4) No criminal suits were filed in any other Court within the limits of the Order.4. Registration. mods.abstract: Annual reports (1915-1927) on the working of The Persian Coast and Islands Order in Council, sent by the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf to the Government of India, Foreign and Political Department, and the India Office. The reports contain information on jurisdiction, civil and criminal cases tried in each area, and registration of British subjects and protected persons.
